Projects originated in intermediate and advanced video and television classes will be accepted. Course may be repeated. An advanced post-production workshop for directors or editors with a current work in progress. Students screen their work in progress on a regular basis and participate in editorial discussions. The class will also explore the whole post-production process (i.e., sound editing, ADR, Foley, and music) and how it can serve to fully realize the potential of each film. Guest visits and tours when possible. 11th Floor Self Guided Walking Tour: Post Production Center: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Undergraduate Film & Television Admissions About the Program Course Offerings Summer Courses Showcase Internships Facilities Special Projects First Run & Festivals Calendar of Events News TSOA FTV Wiki Admin & Faculty Alumni Blog Facebook Twitter YouTube  home > Undergraduate Film & TV        11th Floor Self Guided Walking Tour: Post Production Center   The 11th Floor Production Center can provide everything that a student needs to finish his or her film on site, including staff assistance. At the beginning of the central corridor--to your right is Room 1141, this is the Undergraduate Sound Lab also known as the Pro Tools Lab. You can use this lab to edit sound for freshman sound classes. You will also be here taking tech seminars to learn the various types of audio software. Continue straight down the hall past the intersection to see the sound studios. On your right you will see room 1142. This is the Recording Studio. You can use this studio to record music scores, either wild or synced to picture. The operation of this studio is covered in the Studio Recording class. Walk further down the hall and take a quick right turn down the side hallway, this will take you to nine sound suites, rooms 1125 to 1134. You will use these rooms to record, edit and mix sound as both a fundamentals sound student as well as an advanced sound editor. Go back out to the main corridor and turn right, on your right is the main sound classroom 1143, where you will take Craft classes dealing with sound as well as your freshman sound classes. Further down the hall is room 1144, The Foley Studio is for recording live sound effects that can then be added to your film. You will use this studio to physically create the sound effects with Foley props in sync to picture. You will also have several floor surfaces to record footsteps. If done properly an audience will never notice the added sound. Next is room 1145, the ADR Studio. This studio is used to record and replace poorly recorded location dialogue. Your actors will come in and record existing lines, add lines and tweak the performance based on the way the picture has been edited. At the end of the hall is room 1146 the Mix Studio. This is the final stage for your sound design. In this studio you will make sure all your sound tracks are at the proper level and that everything plays back the way you want it to in a theatre. If you did all the work necessary leading up to this, it will make your film sound like a winner! Head back toward the elevators and make your first right, walking a few feet forward, on your right will be the Post Production checkout window. There are tables and chairs in front of the check out window. There you can take a seat and collaborate with fellow students and faculty members in our vibrant Post Production Center lounge area. Once you've checked into a lab, studio or suite at the Post Production desk, you can proceed to one of the six multi-station computer-editing labs. These rooms are primarily used by freshman, sophomore and junior filmmakers at Kanbar. If you have any questions, please feel free to ask them at the PPC Checkout Window. Thanks for stopping by!   11th Floor Post Production Audio Tour  11th Flr: Post Production Tour (pdf)           Undergraduate Admissions Graduate Admissions Academic Services Student Life Financial Aid and Scholarships Career Development Counseling Services International Students Incoming Students Graduation Forms What is Special Programs? Post Production: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Undergraduate Film & Television Admissions About the Program Course Offerings Summer Courses Showcase Internships Facilities Special Projects First Run & Festivals Calendar of Events News TSOA FTV Wiki Admin & Faculty Alumni Blog Facebook Twitter YouTube  home > Undergraduate Film & TV        Post Production                                          The Post Production Center (PPC) at NYU’s Kanbar  Institute of Film & Television provides all the state-of-the-art hardware,  software applications, and operational/technical support that are necessary to support  the editing needs of an artistic filmmaking community that produces almost 8000  student projects per year.                                         Approximately 150 workstations located on the 10 th   & 11 th floors of Tisch School of the Arts are loaded with Final  Cut Pro, Avid Media Composer, or Pro Tools (or combinations of all three  applications) and are available in various configurations: multi-station  computer labs; single station edit suites; ADR, Foley, Mix & Recording  studios; dubbing/duplication facilities; film & video screening rooms;  Sound FX stations, etc.). Staff  and student workers at the PPC Checkout Window on either floor are there to  give assistance and information based on the Film & Television curriculum.                                           Currently supported formats in the PPC include  HDCAM (NOT HDCAM SR), RED, DVCPRO HD, DVCAM, Panasonic  P2, Sony EX-1, and multiple file formats related to emerging technology such as  AVCHD based camcorders and Canon 7D/5D DSLRs . Students are encouraged to meet with full time PPC staff members  who are available to answer questions about these formats and workflows and to  assist students in finishing their projects. The PPC is open during the  semester seven (7) days per week, 12-14 hours per day. Students should be sure to read the PPC  signage on a weekly basis for updates on important dates such as closings,  weekly workshops, technical seminars, and other events that will add to the  creative experience here at TSOA.
